description.text:
Watch Makerbot TV in style or any video for that matter. Kick back and watch some mini tv (fits perfectly in most studio apartments). 
This an entry for the "The Absurd iPhone Accessory Contest".
I've included the knobs and TV stand together on a plate as well as the TV with and without Makerbot logo.

• Print your TV stand on a Replicator sized build platform.
  • Load up your favorite web video.
  • Slide in your phone and enjoy some quality (miniature) programming.

title: Prusa/Hictop Universal Mount Adapter. MPCNC HicWic Universal to Prusa X Carriage

description.text:
**This adapter moves the nozzle from stock location approximately +40mm on Y axis, and +20mm on X.

OK, so I wanted to mount a cheap spindle motor on my fairly ridged (aluminum extruded frame) Hictop/Prusa i3 3D Printer for light engraving/milling. While I was thinking of a mount design, I realized I had already printed an excellent design for my 4'x8' MPCNC project in the garage! The HicWic universal adapter is ridged enough for milling wood and such, so why not light duty work on a much smaller machine? not to mention all of the already designed mounts for various other tools and quick-changeability!

Here it is. You're welcome.

Download this X-Carriage adapter to easily mount HicWic's 525 Universal Mount Version C (23.5mm conduit) -So remember to print the 525 C version of the mount body (UniversalMount525-C-_23.5_v2)

I made this mount match the original design, including required hardware. I used the same parts I had already acquired for my MPCNC project. So, if you've already got an MPCNC, or are building one, you should already have piles of M3.5 or #6 machine screws. I used #6-32 screws and nylock nuts. let me know if your metric nuts do not fit.

Required Hardware:
4x #6-32 machine screws and nylock nuts (metric M3.5x20)
12x M4x8 to mount carriage (should already have them on your current carriage)
4x M3x16 screws and nylock nuts for securing the sliders

The MK8 extruder mount pictured is composed of the following:
The slider from toownky's thing:1237075
The holder & blower from jwood2's thing:1470280

For additional information on the Universal Mount, please see HicWics original thing:1234989

Post any questions in comments. Cheers!

This jig clamps around a 54mm motor mount to ensure that the centering rings are perpendicular to the motor mount tube. Bolt the two parts of the jig around the motor mount tube check that the jig is perpendicular to the motor mount then apply epoxy to the tube and slide the centering ring down to the jig. I use clothes ping to hold the centering ring to the jig until the epoxy sets, then I remove the jig.

I wanted to 3D print this, but searching long and hard, I couldn't find a 3D model for the Relic Fragment from Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Time, Darkness, and Sky. So, I made one for myself and for others to 3D print. I'm not quite sure what else I really need to put in the description, it's pretty straightforward. One thing is though that the pattern is raised, so if you print it with the flat side down, you will need some support on the flat face. I recommend printing it with the rugged edge down and the flat face up. It results in a much smoother face, while giving the bottom a more believable rocky look.

description.text:
This part is a end plug for a 38mm rocket nose cone. It has 2 nut traps to hold M3 nuts, drill holes in the shoulder of the nose cone and countersink them carefully. Use two M3 flat head screws to attach the plug to the nose cone.

Use a heavy duty screw eye for attaching recovery harness to the nose cone.

This particular plug has a slot to hold a small circuit board to power two LED's attached to the tower on the cover.

Print with ABS or PETG for best results. PLA has a tendency to soften on hot days and should be avoided.

title: Gaming Joysticks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Are you tired of being unable to finish a level in your favorite iPhone game because you lose track of were the controls are? That is now a problem of the past. With a set of printed joysticks, you can now know where the controls are and get tactile feedback on how much you are moving the controls. 
Another benefit of printing your own, is these are parametric. So you can customize the design and sizing to match your favorite game! Plus there is no strange hardware to buy, just add conductive foam.
Have fun!

1) Print out joystick.stl and joystickClip.stl
2) Cut a piece of conductive foam about 10mm x 10mm x 10mm.
3) Place conductive foam cutout in center hole and trim excess away.
4) Connect the joystick and joystick clip together.
5) Place assembly on iPhone.
6) Finish that level that has been giving you grief.

It's not just a print, it's a movement!

Call upon Congress to adopt the giant deep-sea isopod as the National Deep-sea Animal of the United States.

The giant deep-sea isopod, Bathynomus giganteus, is a charismatic, iconic deep-sea species commonly found in the deep waters of the United States, particularly the Gulf of Mexico and Southern Atlantic. This large, recognizable animal, similar to a pill bug or roly poly, can reach almost 2 feet in length. Since their discovery in the late 19th century, giant isopods have captured the public’s imagination, acting as an Ambassador Species for deep-sea ecosystems. Ambassador Species are important for education, exploration, and conservation as they provide a charismatic icon to help introduce people to new and unfamiliar creatures and places.

We call upon the Congress of the United States of America to establish the giant deep-sea isopod, Bathynomus giganteus, as our National Deep-sea Animal.

Read a bit about the biology and ecology of the giant deep-sea isopod in our epic monograph: Sizing ocean giants: patterns of intraspecific size variation in marine megafauna.

Observe the behavior of these mighty and enigmatic arthropods in these two videos:

Giant deep-sea isopod digging a burrow and Giant deep-sea isopod swims away

This print comes in 14 pieces, and yes, they are at original scale. This specimen was huge! I recommend scaling down to at least 50%, if not smaller.

Help me continue to make true-to-life 3D models of marine organisms, as well as my other ocean science initiatives by supporting me on Patreon. Even a dollar or two a month goes a long way towards the continued development of my ocean projects.

Sioux Falls was built on quartzite. In the 19th century, when the first settlers arrived they found that wood was scarce. After Sioux Falls became established, local entrepreneurs realized the pink quartzite that rose in great ripples and low plateaus in the area could be quarried and used for street pavers, buildings and other things.

I don't know where this particular pile of quartzite blocks came from. The pile sits on the west side of Falls Park amidst grass, trees and more unquarried quartzite rising out of the ground. I thought it might be fun to model it just to see how much detail I could capture.

I used an LG G4 phone to snap the photos. I used the manual function and captured all the photos in raw/DNG. I snapped a total of 59 photos.

At home, I imported the photos into Adobe Lightroom where I then worked to even out the exposures, sharpened the details and boosted the contrast slightly. After a final check, I exported the photos as 300ppi JPGs. I know, I should have used TIFs, but I wasn't sure that it would make much of a difference.

After importing the folder containing the photos into Agisoft Photoscan, I used the 'High' settings from the creation of the sparse cloud to the dense cloud to the mesh and finally the texture.

When I was finished, I was surprised at the detail of the model. If you look on top of the pile, you can actually see an individual leaf that was rendered accurately even though it was whisper thin and sticking upwards!

I found the model was far too large to share, so I imported it into Autodesk Remake to carefully reduce the complexity of the mesh while still maintaining the best possible details. Once I was satisfied, I exported the model.

I'm still surprised at the level of detail this hugely reduced model has.

I did not find that one to complete de collection so I made it.

Enjoy

author: SPWA

print_settings.Notes:: Lever requires high infill or it breaks. Body may use down to 30%, but then it requires reinforcement later.

description.text:
This is a compact extruder based on the cheap (both in price and quality) 28BYJ48 stepper motor. It was designed for printing flexible filaments via one channel of a diamond hotend.

Features:

  • Bowden tube out, guided in.
  • Flexible filament friendly: Bowden tube goes right to the gear+bearing set.
  • Quick release lever.
  • Lightweight: 63g
  • Compact: Stepper+square body = the size of a NEMA17 motor.

Known Issues:

  • Requires careful assembly, or the back cover may not fit well (aesthetics only).
  • No mounting holes, it just hangs on the bowden tube.

Printer:

DIY i3

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Parts have embedded support where needed, just make sure your slicer detects thin walls.

Lever requires high infill or it breaks. Body may use down to 30%, but then it requires reinforcement later.

The body should require little cleanup, just make sure teh corners are square where they are supposed to be. Reinforce the bottom of the spring well by gluing a piece cut from a metal washer. The tensioning screw puts a lot of concentrated force there, and may punch a hole through (guess how I know this). Be very careful when inserting the bowden nut, use a file to correct the diameter of the hole, and go back and forth several times while screwing it in.

For the lever you should probably start by drilling the axis hole for the bearing, use a drill small enough that a M3 screw will still grab. After that use a small file to remove the supports where the bearing goes. Insert the bearing (not the screw), place a piece of sandpaper on a flat surface, and sand the sides of the lever untill they are completely flat, an fit inside the body without sticking out. Lock the bearing in place with an M3x8 screw, making sure the head goes inside the slot on the body, and not against the motor.

Use an M3x25 screw, M3 nut and a spring to build the compression system as shown in the photos, and attach it to the lever. Install the lever on the body.

Hack your 28BYJ48 to work as a bipolar motor and use decent drivers (A4988 or DRV8825, not ULN2003). Mount an MK8 extruder gear on the motor making sure the filament channel is close to the motor. Then use two M3x8 screws to hold the motor in place.

The back requires a lot of careful sanding to fit. It may be held in place by press-fit or by 5x5mm cylindrical magnets. I went press-fit, but if you choose to use magnets then sand the back cover until it fits loosely on the extruder. Cut a washer in several pieces and glue 4 of them in the pockets on the inside of the back.

Started with a guide sketch on paper, then made a base model on OpenSCAD. The body and most carvings are basic extrusions of complex shapes, so exported the base mechanics from openscad to DXF, and used librecad to draw most of the body detais. Once the body details were drawn I imported the DXF back into openscad and extruded every layer in the right place.

For the OpenSCAD model build you will need my HCAD library.

comments.text:
400g is a bit weak I think. With proper cooling and therefore increased current you may get higher though.
As for backlash, considering the gear ratio, retraction may be affected. Of course it is not as detrimental as for an axis.
BTW, you don't need a cover that is detrimental to proper cooling.
I currently use a motor, weight about 100g with regular gears (5:1) all salvaged from an old laser printer, total extruder 150g and I get 60 N pull, plenty more than required so a smaller motor could do.
Now, the real killer would be a brushless DC motor with encoder.

Designed this for a friend that is making a full costume. He is going to drill out the jewel and glue in a fake gem, but you can also paint it with red nail polish.
Printed in PETG. I used 0.2mm layer height but you can use lower if you are patient. Don't use larger.

Instructions:
-Print file and remove brim
-Clean up any "zits" or artifacts on the part
-Curve the flat belt buckle (optional):
-preheat the oven to 400F (205C)
-place buckle in a baking dish lined with Aluminum foil
-put part in oven to soften ~2-3 minutes
-watch constantly, if the thinnest areas get shiny take it out
-lift it by the aluminum foil and place it on a large curved surface (I used a propane tank)
-use oven gloves and press the buckle to shape
-pay attention to the lower A section to make sure the two points are still in alignment and aren't twisted. Mine were slightly off so I heated them with lighter and fixed them.
Painting (optional):
-paint with a metallic grey paint and primer spray
-spray at all angles and apply 3-4 coats, but not too much in one coat as it will hide features. Multiple coats are needed so you don't strip the paint down to the plastic in the following steps.
-allow to fully dry (1 day)
-spray 1 full coat of flat black spray paint on top of the grey
-wait 1 minute for the paint to get slightly tacky (time varies a lot based on the brand)
-dip a rag or "shop towel" in paint thinner and ring it out, then rub the black spray paint off all the raised surfaces. Rubber/latex gloves aren't a bad idea ;)
-use another rag with the same treatment to finish the job and for a brighter metal appearance redo key areas (the first rag will have a lot of black in it)
-let dry fully

comments.text:
Hi. Great looking model but I tried to print this on my Taz 6 single head printer but it wend badly wrong. This could be my fault but I'm not sure I could have done anything differently.
I split the model in half using Cura and then selected 20% infill. When the (half) model was printing the head kept being pushed hard into the internal main shaft cylinder around 3mm high into the build. Basically this model is not a simple outer shell - instead it has internal structures that when combined with automatic infill, seem to cause Cura to generate bad gcode causing the head to crash into the print as it is being made.
I've been able to print other models so any feedback appreciated.

description.text: The two calibration switches on the bathroom scale failed (plastic feet broke).  They are used to prevent being weighed until the scale is calibrated to zero.  Decided to put the new switch plate on top because more space was available.

Print Parts, Part 1 is the retaining cover, Part 2 is the button, Part 3 is the switch base . . .
Drill hole in scale cover and hole in Part 3, lead calibration wires through hole, attach one part of calibration metal lead (+) to standoff in base, the other part of calibration metal lead (-) to standoff on button . . . 
Place flexible weather stripping in base to act as spring . . .
Place button into base and adjust calibration metal leads (by bending) to make contact when weatherstripping is compressed . . .
Place retaining cover over top of button and base to retain button inside base, drill hole in back of retaining cover for a screw to press against the backside of the base . . .
Use double sticky tape to attach assembly to scale cover . . .

description.text:
Created a solid frame for F3 Evo board from bang good. Uses a combination of pressfits to mount the camera, the motors, and the flight controller.

Can uses 55mm or 65mm props. Designed for 65mm and is about 64g total weight with a 720mah battery.

Utilize rubber bands (dental bands) for holding battery in place.

Tight fit for motor mounts to prevent wires from being removed from the base of the motors.
The previous version of this where the frame was 2 grams lighter, did not increase performance enough to justify the constant breaking of motor wires.

The camera mount and camera info can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1734830

Printer:

i3 prusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Use PETG.
.8 mm nozzle highly recommended. I can print this frame in 30 minutes or less. Limited to .2mm layer height with a .4mm nozzle it was taking over 90 minutes to print successfully. There has been zero alteration to motor mounts or any press fit parts when going from .4mm to .8mm nozzles.

don't be like me and waste your life waiting for a simple print like this to finish. We're making quad frames not miniatures!

Flight Controller

I centered the flight controller and started with a thin extrude so that I could get an idea of the center of gravity of the frame.

Iteration of the design was required to remove material in key locations around and beneath the flight controller. This is a large distinction from my previous quad frames.

I removed material for the FETS, motor solder pads, and the power pads so that a flush press fit could be achieved.

Image showing the 4 cutouts for the FETs and then the cutouts for USB and power pads (bottom of the FC box). Re used image from the dreamweaver frame as both use the same FC box.

description.text:
This is a mounting bracket for a 40mm cooling fan for the controller board in the Monoprice Select Mini 3D printer. It can be used to cool the controller board with the addition of a 40mm fan.
Also included is a separate mount for a small auxiliary PCB that I designed to control the fan so that is only runs when the hot end is heating. This also controls the LEDs and the cooling fan for the hot end, so I can use the built-in fan for part cooling.

The schematics and details of this fan control circuit are included on our Hack-a-Day project page, so if you'd like to learn more about it, then check out the page linked here: https://hackaday.io/project/14823-monoprice-select-mini-maximum-3d-printer-mods/log/48494-what-to-do-if-youre-not-a-fan-of-constantly-running-fans

title: Magpul M-lok System Components
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
All of these variations are BASED on the M-LOK system by Magpul.

Please support the DEVs
https://www.magpul.com/search-results?PID=88&eComQuery=mlok&ProductNumber=mlok

I have included the 3, 5, 7, 9, and 11 Slot rails. I plan on developing the Cantilever and other commonly used mounts as well. I have used 8-32 (1/2" or 3/4" round [button] head) (3/4" or 1" flat [countersunk] head) phillips head screws and nuts to secure these to my hand guard. A 10-32 1/2" or 5/8" screw will work but may require some additional material removed from the rail so the screw can pass through the rail. A 10-32 will grab the included T-nut quite well from testing. A Hex nut may be large enough to allow for modification so that some material from the mating face can be removed and allow for it to lock into the rail with an oval footprint.

** I used a #10-32 x 3/4" flat head phillips(countersunk) for use with the tnut. as you can see in the photos there is a bit of thread left over so shorter is a acceptable but i wanted to make sure that i had positive thread engagement.

I am not staking claim or utilizing the trademark to my advantage in anyway, just a way for you to find this.

I borrowed the T-nut and used the 5 slot as a template to cut a majority of the work away. Thanks User Ripper121. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1827154

Printer:

qu3d(QUbD) variation

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50% infill with 115% modifier

Notes:

Supports are required to get the lift and bridging, infill amount is subjective. i have had very strong prints using PLA with this infill level.

This nice, easy to print vase will be a nice gift for friend or family to come along with some nice flowers!

1) Download file
2) Generate gcode
The 3D STL is a closed file. I used Skeinforge to slice my prints (third one printing now). The 3D model is quiet tall @200mm and may not fit your 3D printer. Rescale or chop the top part to fit your printer.
Here's what I did generating gcode:
  • 3 bottom layers
  • No fill (obviously)
  • 1 extra shell (making 2 shells on wall)
  • Layer height 0,3 (to save print time)
  • Remove the top 3 layers by hand (after gcode was generated)
    3) Choose a color.
    I personally like the semi-transparent materials for these objects.
    4) Print the vase. It takes 2:30 up to 3:00 hours on my standard Ultimaker with SF settings as described above. The result is a pretty strong and good-looking vase!
    5) Enjoy!

comments.author: drmakneeo

comments.text: To help everyone that is asking, The model is solid to allow different nozzle sized printers to print this. If you are using Slic3r, simply slice it with your normal settings, but check the "spiral vase" option ( http://slic3r.org/blog/tip-printing-vases ). If you are using Cura, set it to 0% infill and save it as Gcode. I would recomend opening it in Notepad++ and doing "ctr+f" type in "layer" and select "find all in current document". Find which line the third to last time it says layer, and delete everything up until ";End GCode". That will remove the last three layers. As for the material, ABS and PLA will work. Just make sure that you have a proper cooling system. If printing it with the default settings does not work, increase fan speed and decrease print speed.

description.text: It's Movember 2016 and Global Print Initiative is hosting a contest for the best beard. I decided to include printed beards in the contest. Please take a second and vote for your favorite. Each vote is $1 and it goes to Global Print Initiative a 501(c)3 charity that brings 3D printers to hard to reach places and teaches them the skills to run a print shop to allow them to support local good will initiatives. At the end of the competition, the winner gets to choose what charity or school will get a 3D Printer.

Printer:

GPrint Box

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

The model as is will print perfectly with a .3 first layer and .2 for the rest of the layers. if you want it to fit do some measurements. You can either super glue the left and right side or if you have a big enough bed print the full beard.

Thermal Forming

After printing the beard and gluing it together, use a heat gun or a hairdryer to mold the beard to your face. Please be careful, any temperature that is hot enough to manipulate the plastic will be hot enough to BURN YOUR FACE!

OnShape and pictures

I took a couple of picture of my beard from straight on and on the side view. Then I added the images individually to OnShape and traced over the left side of my beard. I then mirrored the image and extruded

author: syncky

description.text:
When I started with my Geetech Prusa Al, the noise, a mix of humming, hissing, rattling ... almost drove me mad. I had noticed the smooth rods excessive play in the bearings. Worse, they are regular "soft" stainless steel diam 7.92mm ! May be they produce it in that size to sell them as metrinch ? (standard metric 8mm and archaic 5/16 " ). Big savings anyway and it seems to be quite common. I replaced them with suitable hardened rods miked at 7.95 mm.
Now, to reduce further any play and compensate for slight misalignment, I designed these bearings where the LM8U is held by two O rings. Depending on the O ring size, material, shore hardness one can make the liaison more or less flexible. This somewhat allows to constrain the bearings when they are mounted thus eliminating any play.

Yes, tie wraps and flexible frame achieve about the same result but frankly ?

It is a drop in replacement for the SC8UU. Use self tapping screws (old printers are a good source for perfect ones). Regular machine screws are not really fit for plastic but will work. No real need to tap, just make sure the hole is the screw diam mius the pitch (eg M3: 3-0.5 = 2.5)

PS: These have been printed in ABS with an unimproved Geetech. I don't use them anymore as I went Igus (see my other things). Of course the quality while not bad is not comparable to what I am now getting. Biggest gain due to replacing the Z lead screws and one motor. See my other things.

I built a frame of three lithopanes with a light-dependent circuit. The circuit has three green LEDs, an LDR and a transistor. It has an enclosure that I built in Tinkercad and the top comes off so that I can replace the batteries when I need to.
Just removed the Triforce as I didnt like how high it was

I needed to firmly hold my bronzefill Maker coin ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1862575 ) in order to polish it but without crushing any of the details. I did not see any of this style vice on Thingiverse so I made one.

Print one of each STL file. The inclined part of the wedges should be sanded a bit to remove the "steps" so they slide smoothly against each other to close the vice.

The vice is much more secure than it looks and will hold any small object up to about 38mm x 38mm but can be scaled up for larger objects (within reason). The inserts hold most small things, but you can easily customize them to gently hold specific shapes. It fits together into a compact "puck" when not in use.

Printed at .3mm, three perimeters, three top/bottom layers and 50% infill is more than strong enough. I used eSun ABS but I'm going to try some of their PLA+ since it's supposed to be tougher (and we're neighbors so they give me samples for free;-)

comments.text: The wedges are similar to the ones used in letterpress printing. They're called "quoins". See the Wikipedia listing for some details. By putting in the "teeth" that can be engaged by a "quoin key", they can produce a surprising amount of pressure. (And, it's possible, by careful application of multiple quoins to "clamp" surprisingly large items.)

title: Kossel/Delta LED strip light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A LED strip holder for Kossel printer (but may be adapted to other).

The provided STL file are design for my Kossel XL 2020 printer (a Renren 3D Pro, really good chinese printer by the way).

It can be used to add 2 x 30cm LED strip (8mm width). Each strip holder came in two parts, the base and the extension, allowing it to be print on any 20cmx20cm common size printer.

A connector box is also included, that can contains a micro switch, and a bunch of connectors (up to 5 Molex KK254 for example). All these components can be solder in a simple piece of perfboard. On connector received the power, that pass through the switch, and then go to the other connector, Other connectors can be used to power multiple led strips.

I added the OpenScad source file, to the parts can be adapted to any printer. I use the most variable as possible at the begnining of the .scad, that should allow you to change every aspect (lenght, with, angle, profile size, led strip size...).

If you use to make LED strip holder for a specific type or printer, do not hesitate do create a remix with the printer in reference please, for other peoples :).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Renren 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Support (everywhere, not only bed based) are needed for the strips. Print them as is in the STL file, which means the side that will be on the profile at the bottom (on the bed).

The connector box is easy to print, no support need. Just print the switch face on the bottom (you need to rotate the provided STL file by 90°).

DISCLAIMER: This is for informational purposes only. Settings, workflow and figures may need to be adapted individually. I refuse any reliability in cases of demages or injuries.

  • set Z-elevation to 30mm (length of the bolt used)
  • generate automatic supports (pilar size 1mm)
  • manually remove all supports within the hole and the space for the bolt head
  • save gcode-file
  • open gcode-file with text editor and find starting point of the first layer above the bolt head (next of Z=40,15mm for a 30mm Z-elevation)
  • add following code before that layer 
    ;pause
G1 Z110 F1200       ;lower heat bed to Z=110mm
G1 X110 Y70 F4200   ;move printhead to back right
M104 S0 T0          ;cool down extruder
M146 r0 g255 b0     ;set light to green
M25                 ;pause print job
M146 r255 g0 b0     ;set light to red
M104 S230 T0        ;set extruder to 230°C
M6 T0               ;wait for extruder to reach target temp
M146 r255 g255 b255 ;set light to white
  • start print
paused print job
  • when print job paused insert bolt
paused print job - the green light is awesome ;-) paused print job with bolt inserted
  • resume print job
finished view of finished job from print bed side - note the bolt in the center detached support structure

comments.text:
You can pause on specify layer by S3D script additional terminal command via SD cards below
M25 it dreamer pause command

title: Renren 3D Pro (Kossel XL) acrylic top plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Renren 3D Pro is a Delta printer, base on Kossel XL design.

Electronics is on the top, by default without protection.
So I create a top plate, in 5mm tickness laser cutted acrylic. The DXF file can be used to cut it (I didn't cut it myself, I order it from a local provider).

The plate have a center hole for a 60mm fan, to cool down the electronic card.

I also added 3D printed part to support and fix the acrylic plate.

This was created specificaly for the Renren 3D Pro printers. But it may works or may be adapted to some other Delta printer with the following characteristics:

  • Base on Kossel orginal design
  • Frame in 2020 extruded profil aluminum
  • Top 2020 frame are 28cm length

I won't support or made change for other type of printer, but if you want to try, feel free to do it. If it works, add a comment to tell it, with the printer type, so that I can add it in a "compatibility list". Add a remix it needed for specific parts.

title: Raspberry Pi Case Mount for FolgerTech FT-5

description.text:
I use my Raspberry Pi 3 to control my 3D printers but I also wanted it portable so I could take it with me without being tethered to a power cord. That led me to follow this path > http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1503651 which is a battery powered option with a 7" Raspi screen. After I built the FolgerTech FT-5, I couldn't find an easy way to mount the heavy case and the attached camera since the build surface is very high.
This led me to the simple bracket that slides over the electronics cabinet of the FT-5 and prevents the Raspi case from being knocked off. It also gets it high enough that, with a long ribbon cable, the camera can be mounted up on the top rail. That mount will be presented in another 'thing'.
I'm attaching both the stl file and the 123D Design file so that you can make it fancy if you choose (radii, etc) or modify it to fit your case.

Also, realized that I might need access to the USB ports on the Raspberry Pi if I'm using a dongle or hooking it to the USB port on the FT-5, so the 'modified' version provides that access.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal RPi Camera Bed Mount

title: Anet A8 Rpi camera Bed mount

description.text:
2016.11.09 Added v3, based on v2 but with longer horizontal arm. With bed all forward and extruder at the far right, it has 0.5 cm gap from lens :)

2016.11.04 Added v2 that is very stiff and won't wobble. This is shorter, but you can't use the macro lens with this or it will hit the X axys. Working on v3..
Also added a timelapse video recorded with v1. Lights are very poor, that should be the next mod :D

Mounting a camera for timelapse\web monitoring was an idea I had from the beginning.
So when I started planning the installation of OctoPrint I was looking around for a camera mount. The key was mounting the camera on the printer bed so resulting timelapse are much better.
I found the beautiful mount design from Jerware http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:442063 and tried to adapt it for our Anet A8 (thus maybe it is good for other Prusa i3 printers too).
So the back\front camera case and tilt arm are Jerware's original design, while the camera arm mount is my remix.

You need:

  • Raspberry PI Camera (v1 or v2 - v2 has better quality);
  • Rpi camera extension cable http://www.gearbest.com/raspberry-pi/pp_451150.html?wid=21 I bought three different sizes for maximum versatility;
  • (optional, but recommended) 0.67 X Detachable Wide Angle Macro Camera Lens for Mobile Phones http://www.ebay.it/itm/122118851619?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=421705232711&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT it's only 1,30 eur and you have a perfect wide camera lens for this application!

Check out all my Anet A8 projects:

  • Anet A8 Prusa i3 Simple filament guide (Horizontal) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764285
  • Anet A8 RPi Camera Bed mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1867549
  • Anet A8 Y Axis Cable Chain v2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1915486
  • Anet A8 hotbed thermal insulation http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1917197
  • Anet A8 Power supply cover w\LCD power meter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2087761
  • Anet A8 Z-Axis RPi Camera mount for panning timelapses http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2265949
  • Anet A8 LED Illumination MOD http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285674
  • The One - Anet A8 - Universal Spool Holder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456038

Printer:

Anet A8 (Prusa i3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Place the RPi Camera inside the case, the case inside the tilt arm and then on the bed mount. You must place the mount not on the heated bed itself but on the bottom aluminium tray. The mount is thin enough to not hit the printer parts at the bottom.

I designed it with front installation in mind, that's the reason fot the extra-long horizontal mount. After that I changed to back installation and a shorter mount will work too and will have less vibrations, so stay tuned for version 2.

Tip: if you have a v2 camera you should thin a bit the inner edge of the back camera case, you can see two small black dots in one picture.

I'm a real beginner here. I used Tinkercad and now I'm trying to learn 123D Design.

Bed mount v2 timelapse

title: E3D V6 Mount for the Ultimaker 2

description.text:
The E3D V6 mount By Raix was designed for the ultimaker original.

This design is for the UM2.

EDIT: The fans orientation is not good. Its on the Y axis (front-back). By using the larger fans the end stops have to be moved, because the fan is hitting the Y motor, thus losing a lot of the build space.
Also Raix got upset and removed the editable files for the mount thus editing the design is pretty hard.
I do believe that using the smaller fans is fine.

The distances between the axis is different, so I modified it to be 18 mm.
Not the most professional modding solution but it works.

The rest of the mount are the same. Also keep in mind that the fan holders are a little miss aligned.

title: GPS pouch holder brackets for motorbike steering bar

description.text:
In need of a better way to attach my GPS to the steering bar of my Yamaha X-MAX, I used my pipe brackets http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1859966, skewed the base plate, added a block as pipe collar and changed defaults. I now enjoy a centered navigation device display, where it was mounted to the left mirror before, close to the left handle. Peripheral vision is now sufficient to catch a glimpse of the map, a big improvement over earlier state.

Technically this would be a remix, but not published a such as this thing is made for an entirely different purpose.

Parametrisation hasn't been tested thoroughly. But within reasonable margins of parameters, I expect the resulting thing to make some sense. Base angle shouldn't be set too tilted, because the bores for the screws will be accordingly arched.

Printed as two parts (each side) as this supports rotating the parts according expected vector of forces, and for easier printing. Block tabs are kept same height as collars - and consequently the used screws - for strengthening the weakest dimension.

Soon I may be able to update the photos, showing the items with a much thinner carbon fiber rod, instead of the currently used steel rod. It will also carry centered attachments for a hanging mount point, above the GPS pouch, thereby moving the whole pouch downwards. This helps to reduce obstruction of viewing instruments.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.28mm/layer

Infill:

50% (probably overkill, I wanted to be on the safe side)

After printing I assembled the parts, using for each side:
2x screw M3*40
4x washers
4x nut M3 (2 used as locknuts)

and for tightening the tabs:
1x screw M3x30
2x washers
2x nut M3 (1 used as locknut)

As pipe, a cut-off from a steel clothes hanging pipe, taken from a cupboard, with diameter of a tad above 24mm (the pipe, not the cupboard) was used. Most parts were then fleetingly subjected to black varnish from a spray can, matching the vehicle colour.

You may want to drill a hole through at least one side of pipe collar and pipe, for a tapping screw, to keep the pipe from rotating along X axis, especially if center of gravity of the GPS pouch falls considerable outside the pipe perimeter. I should have placed a rail through the inside of the collar base, and cut two notches into each end of the pipe, into which the rail could insert into.

Versions:

v0.0.1 2016Nov02, Bushmills initial version
v0.0.2 2016Nov06, Bushmills changed rod from 24mm steel to 16mm carbon fibre
added rod rotation preventing rails, requiring grooves at rod ends
